sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Eh!—what! good God!

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Let me look at you—good God!—don't be alarmed.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: But I am very much alarmed. Am I ill?

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: I dare ſay you feel— flurried.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Exceedingly.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Palpitation at the heart'—'tis parchment?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Oh yes—very ſudden this. I felt quite well juſt now.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Did you? That's an alarming ſymptom; for I have always obſerved, that nothing makes the phyſcian look ſo grave, as the patient's ſaying he feels quite well. My dear friend, ſend for one directly.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: I don't know what to ſay, They ſometimes ſave your life; but then it is ſure to coſt you a guinea.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: And ſaving yours is certainly not worth it. But I ſee you are a philoſopher—You are prepared for death,

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Oh dear! not at all—I am quite terrified. If perſpiration is good for me, I feel that copiouſly.—What ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Come, for old acquaintance ſake, my grandſon ſhall attend you gratis.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Oh, thank you.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Wonderful phyſician! Never loſt a patient—! (aſide.) becauſe he never had a patient to loſe. I expect him here in five minutes. You had better go to your room.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Aye.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Keep yourſelf warm.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Above all things, don't change your clothes.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: I won't.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Shall I button your coat?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: No, no—I'll do that myſelf.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Go, I'll follow, and talk to you of your latter end, and keep up your ſpirits.
I believe I am dying. 'Tis very good of you to get me a doctor gratis, (exit, and re-enters.) But I ſay—who is to pay the apothecary?

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: I'll ſettle that too.—(Exit Nicholas.)—Now for Undermine—If he have one ſpark of humanity in his compoſition, I'll call it forth; if not, and I can get that coat—

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Nicholas! What April here—I gueſs your errand, and am ſorry, ſir, I cannot continue you as ſteward.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: I your ſteward! No, that is not my errand, I am a feeble fellow, ſliding out of the world; but Greville is a noble fellow riſing into it. 'Tis reſpecting him I come. You muſt aſſiſt him. How is he to live?

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Oh! his integrity will ſupport him.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p:
True; but conſider what a way you
would be in, if you had nothing but your integrity to ſupport you.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Sir, I ſee you only want to triflle with me.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: True; I only want a trifle of you.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: I am flint.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Well; but even flint, when properly hit, will ſend forth warm, vivid ſparks.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: I muſt leave you. Time preſſes.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: So do his wants.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: A nobleman is waiting for me.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: A bailiff is waiting for him.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: If you proceed, expect ſome perſonal inſult.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Throw your purſe at me. Come—

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: I ſhall burſt with rage.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: They will famiſh with hunger.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Unhand me, I ſay.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: What, a blow!

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Yes; take him that.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: No, no, that you meant for myſelf, and I'll take it, ſo you will give ſomething better to poor Greville.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: I will not.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: You ſcoundrel! And do you ſuppoſe, that becauſe I would ſubmit to a blow to endeavour to ſave a friend from ruin, that I want the ſpirit of a man to reſent an indignity. Aſk my pardon.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Pardon!

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Aye.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: I do—help! help!

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: On your knees, or your laſt hour is come.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Well, I do—I do, Help! help!

div.stage: Enter Two Servants.—April throws Undermine from him, who retreats behind the Servants.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Leave my houſe, ſir, leave my houſe. By heaven, I'll be revenged.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: By hell, you are a villain.

div.head: SCENE I.—Outſide of UNDERMINE'S houſe.
div.stage: Enter ROSTRUM and EGERTON with caution.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: That is the houſe.

sp.speaker: Eger.
sp.p: Does that contain—

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Softly—recollect, ſir, you are only a ſubaltern in this affair, and that I am your commanding officer; ſo, obey orders.

sp.speaker: Eger.
sp.p: How do you intend to proceed?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: I am too great a general to communicate my plan of operations; I ſhall do my duty in giving you poſſeſſion of the lovely citadel, and then take care and do your duty. (going.) I ſay, when the alarm is given, do you retreat—you know how to do that, I dare ſay.

sp.speaker: Eger.
sp.p: I fear to truſt my happineſs. Can it be poſſible that my adored girl ſtill thinks with kindneſs on her poor Egerton? Ah! a noiſe—what an anxious moment!

div.stage: Enter Rostrum from the houſe, with Miſs SYDNEY in one band, and repelling UNDERMINE with the other.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: I will carry her off.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: You ſhall not, ſir, I am her guardian.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Do you think I care for guardians? dare to ſtir hand or foot, and I'll cruſh you into atoms, you old ſcoundrel. (during this, Egerton diſcovers himſelf to Miſs Sydney, who runs into his arms.)

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: That will do—zounds! be quiet—they are gone, I tell you.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Eh! ſo they are, ha, ha!—well, how did I do it?

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Oh, capitally— (rubbing his arm.) has the ſoldier got her?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: That's as it ſhould be.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Exactly.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Well!

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Well!

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Are you mad?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: The matter! why don't you go?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Why zounds! how can you marry the girl if you ſtand here.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: I marry! oh, very true. I declare it quite eſcaped me.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! run.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: I am a-going, a-going, a-going— (returning.) Sir! where ſhall I bring the bride?

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: To Greville's. Go along.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: I ſay—this is management.

sp.speaker: Und
sp.p: Yes, yes—but go along.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Sir, you would make a capital puff at an auction.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Zounds! go. (exit Roſtrum.) So that's ſettled—and now to Greville's in triumph. I'll walk in with erected creſt, and—ugh! confound the fellow, how he has bruiſed me!

div.head: SCENE II.—An Apartment at Mr. UNDERMINE'S.
div.stage: NICHOLAS diſcovered on a couch. APRIL ſitting by him with a book.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: I wiſh the doctor were come.—Bleſs me, I hope I ſhan't die—I don't care what pain I ſuffer, ſo I don't die. Oh! for a ſwinging rheumatiſm that would laſt me twenty years—do read a little to me.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: "Crumbs of comfort for an aged ſinner."

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Theſe books are quite new to me.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Have you had my letter?

sp.speaker: Pleth.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Don't forget—'tis the coat I want—and remember you are a phyſician, not a farrier.

sp.speaker: Pleth.
sp.p: I will—and if I ſucceed, remember you tip. How do you do?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: That's what I want to know of you.

sp.speaker: Pleth.
sp.p: True—oh I ſee—

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Shall I detail my ſymptoms?

sp.speaker: Pleth.
sp.p: No—'tis a clear caſe—if you were to talk for an hour, I ſhould not know more of your complaint than I do at preſent.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Bleed him—

sp.speaker: Pleth.
sp.p: I will. You have no objection to part with a little blood?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: I have an objection to part with any thing.

sp.speaker: Pleth.
sp.p:
Except to advantage. Now, if by ſinking an ounce or two of blood, you can produce an
income of ſixteen pounds of fleſh, the advantage is immenſe.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: How ſenſibly he talks! why, 'tis five thouſand per cent profit. I'll be bled directly.

sp.speaker: Pleth.
sp.p: Help him.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: No, no, I can do that myſelf. (places the coat carefully under the cuſhion of the ſopha.—As he ſits down, April ſlips the coat from under the cuſhion, winks to Plethora, and exit on tiploe.) 'Tis very terrifying—I'll read a little more. But, doctor, are you ſure now I ſhall not be ſuddenly called to heaven.

sp.speaker: Pleth.
sp.p: I am very ſure of that.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Oh, you are. (throwing away the book.) Then, pray, ſir, what is my complaint?

sp.speaker: Pleth.
sp.p: Complaint! what ſhall I ſay? I wiſh he would return—oh, 'tis the—the glanders.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: The glanders! zounds! do you make a horſe of me?

sp.speaker: Pleth.
sp.p: No—we will be content with making an aſs of you. (aſide.)—(Enter April with the coat and will, which he exhibits to Plethora in triumph.) Or perhaps the diſorder may be ſeated in the coats belonging to the ſtomach.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: No, no—the diſorder was ſeated in the coat belonging to the back, ha, ha! but now 'tis removed, (throwing him his coat.) Do you ſee this?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: I am undone.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: And how the devil could you expect a moment's eaſe with ſuch a thing as this laying next your heart—you may go—you are quite cured.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Cured! I am ruined. Oh! if I had but touched the thouſand pounds, I would not mind the intereſt—perhaps 'tis not too late.

sp.speaker: April
sp.p: Sole heir without reſervation or reſtriction; huzza!

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Sir, honourable ſir, will you allow me to aſk you one ſmall favour?

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Only to delay mentioning this (ſighing.) joyful diſcovery for a few moments. My maſter and I have a little account to ſettle, and I ſhould like juſt to ſtrike a balance before he knows what has happened.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Oh, I underſtand—we have bled you, and now you want to go and bleed him.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Juſt a little, ſir.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: With all my heart, old Nick. Devil claw devil.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Oh, thank you, ſir.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: But diſpatch—

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: I fly, ſir.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Now with heels as light as our hearts we'll away to Greville's.

sp.speaker: Pleth.
sp.p: Stop—ſtop for me, grandfather.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, old one. Here take my arm—let your grandfather aſſiſt you. Upon my ſoul, I quite forget you.

div.head: SCENE III.—An elegant Drawing room in GREVILLE'S houſe, illuminated.—A band of muſic playing.—A number of Servants dreſſed in ſplendid liveries.
div.stage: Enter UNDERMINE in great elation, joining the muſic in, "See the conquering hero," &c.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Approach! is Greville gone?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Not yet, ſir.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Any of my gueſts arrived?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: No, ſir.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Has the Traiteur furniſhed a ſplendid entertainment?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes, ſir.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Let muſic uſher in the gueſts.

div.stage: Enter APRIL ſinging—"See the conquering hero," &. flouriſhing the will in his hand; ſeeing Undermine, he conceals it.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Zounds! he here.— (to the Servant.)— Don't go away, ſir.

div.stage: (places the Servant between him and April.)

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: How do you do?

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: How do you do?

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: I have overcome my paſſion, and thought better.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Oh, very well—then 'tis all over.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: You impudent raſcal, how dare you ſtand between me and my friend?— Begone, you ſcoundrel!—I thought you would ſee the abſurdity of my ſupporting Greville.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Oh yes; it would have been quite out of character.

div.stage: Muſic plays. Rostrum, ſinging—"See the conquering hero," &c. enters leading in EGERTON and ROSE SYDNEY.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Heyday! my ward here! why, girl—?
sp.stage: (goes up to her, and they converſe in dumb ſhew.)

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Come here—come here—give me your hand, you dog—I ſuppoſe 'tis all ſettled.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: It is—the wedding's over.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: I ſay—what will that old fool April ſay, I wonder?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: We ſhall hear.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: I underſtand. Mr. Undermine, have you given our ward permiſſion to marry?

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: To be ſure I have.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: If that be the caſe, my dear, you have mine.

sp.speaker: Eger.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: He thank me! what has he to do with it. Oh! I forgot he helped you to this delicious morſel.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: No, he did not; he helped himſelf—and what is more, perſuaded a parſon to ſay grace.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Egerton her huſband! Did not I order you to marry her? Did not I bid—

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: You did bid, ſir; but honor bid more.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: I give you joy, my girl. You have choſen a noble fellow.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Well, and I give her joy, for ſhe has choſen a beggar.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: On that point I beg to be heard. You remember you gave me a key—here it is.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Well, ſir?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: It belonged, ladies and gentlemen, to an eſcrutoire, with a ſecretary drawer. Pannells richly fineered—ſcrole pediment head—bracket feet—the whole finiſhed in a workmanlike manner, and well worth the attention—

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: At the auctioneer again. Zounds! you are ſo fond of it, I dare ſay you would ſell me.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Sir, I would knock you down with all the pleaſure in life.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: But what of the key?—the key—

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p:
The key certainly opened the drawer you
mentioned; and it as certainly opened a drawer you did not mention.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Be quiet. There I found a parcel of papers, and title deeds, which you muſt have put there entirely by miſtake, my dear ſir, becauſe I perceived they belonged to Mr. Egerton.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Give them to me directly, directly—I ſay, ſir, reſtore—

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Every thing to its right owner. Certainly —I don't wiſh to keep your, or any man's property —ſo, Egerton, there are your papers again— and, Uncle, there is your key again.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Eger.
sp.p: What diſintereſted integrity!

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: What damned raſcality!

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Oh fie! no, no.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: What is it then?

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Management.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Well, you have managed finely for yourſelf however—I diſcard you. Had you followed my inſtructions, you would have been exalted—

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: To the pillory, I ſuppoſe.—No ſir, tho' you don't ſcruple it to others, far be it from me to rob you of your natural inheritance.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: I would have left you all I am worth.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: What then? you forget all you are worth belongs to other people. When you were gone, they would naturally aſk me for their own, and how could I have the face to refuſe them?

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Give me your hand. You have acted your part nobly; and now 'tis my turn.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: All this I laugh at. Am I not poſſeſſed of the Greville eſtate? Who has any thing to ſay on that ſubject!

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: I believe I ſhall trouble you with a word or two.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: I ſee Greville is about to depart, and I muſt beg you will all follow his example.

div.stage: Enter Mr. and Mrs. GREVILLE, SALLY following with a ſmall bundle, and weeping.

sp.speaker: Eger.
sp.p: My beſt friends, allow me to preſent to you a ſiſter. By this gentleman's kindneſs, Maria, happineſs again dawns upon us.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: And I will make it blaze with meridian ſplendour.

sp.speaker: Grev.
sp.p: Let us then leave this man to the full enjoyment of ſuch reflections as his conſcience may adminiſter.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: I beg your pardon a moment. Umph! Mr. Undermine, I hear doubts have ariſen reſpecting the authenticity of the late Mr. Greville's ſignature.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Indeed!—Sir, to ſhew my fairneſs, I'll leave this point to your deciſion.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: 'Tis genuine, it muſt be confeſſed.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Muſt it ſo?

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Any objection to my reading it?

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: None.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Perhaps it may tire you?

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: By no means. I think it remarkably entertaining.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: I, Robert Greville, do declare this my laſt will.— To my only ſon, Charles Greville, I give and bequeath my forgiveneſs and my bleſſing, together with all my eſtates real and perſonal.— Umph! that is very entertaining.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Very—but I prefer the remainder—"Provided my ſaid ſon"—go on—go on.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: What do you ſay?

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: 'Pſhaw!—"Provided my ſaid ſon has not "contracted"—why don't you go on?

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: I don't ſee any thing like it.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: You don't—ha, ha! Give me leave to direct your attention.
sp.stage: (looks at the will, drops his hat and cane, and groans deeply.)

sp.speaker: Grev.
sp.p: What does this mean!

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Mean!—That my young maſter, my friend, my dear Charles, is happy—that my old maſter is in heaven, and that I am in heaven; two wills were made; by the laſt, which he endeavoured to ſuppreſs, you are ſole heir, without reſervation.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Grev.
sp.p: Is it poſſible?

sp.speaker: Grev.
sp.p: How ſhall I expreſs my gratitude for this diſcovery?—for giving happineſs to my Maria?

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: And to me too. Oh, you are a nice old man.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: He muſt have dealt with—

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Old Nick. You are right—I did—and here he comes.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Ah, Nicholas—Nicholas!

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Ah, maſter—maſter!

sp.speaker: Und
sp.p: A dreadful affair this!

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Very ſhocking indeed, ſir.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Eh—zounds! I have given him a draft for a thouſand pounds. (coaxingly.) Nicholas— Come here, Nicholas. I am not angry. My conſolation is, what's done, can't be undone. I gave you a draft—

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: You did, ſir. And my conſolation is, what's done, can't be undone.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Indeed! But it will be of no uſe. I have no caſh at my banker's.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Dear ſir, what credit you have! They paid it without a word.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: You have not been—

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Yes, ſir—I juſt contrived to hobble there.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: You infernal! (gulping down his paſſion.) Old friends ſhould not quarrel, Nicholas; ſuppoſe we go home, and talk it over agreeably. I'll propoſe ſomething reaſonable.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: It muſt be very reaſonable.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: It ſhall. Gentlemen—

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: What, bowing! You forget, ſir, your own leſſons.—Be erect, and I'll tell you how you may be ſo;—become an honeſt man, and on my life, that will make you hold up your head more gallantly than the firſt dancing maſter in Europe can;—depend on't, ſir. Roguery is the worſt trade a man can follow; for (to the credit of human nature) I ſincerely believe, that where one fortune is raiſed by purſuing the devious mazes of chicanery, a hundred are acquired by walking in the ſimple path of induſtrious integrity.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: You had better ſtick to management!

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Management!—Oh, I have had enough of that.

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p: Now, being all as happy as heart can wiſh, come along with me, Sally. Good bye to you—

sp.speaker: Grev.
sp.p: Where are you going, April?

sp.speaker: April.
sp.p:
To the kitchen. I have no notion of your houſes, not I, where all the joy is confined to
the drawing-room. Let there be degrees in every thing but happineſs; and 'fore George, if any ſervant in this houſe be ſober enough to wait on you at ſupper, I'll diſcharge him to-morrow morning. —Poor fellows! muſt not make them ill tho' Never mind—Come along Sally.

sp.speaker: Sally.
sp.p: Oh, you are a nice old man!

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: If I muſt have thanks, gentlemen, let me receive them here!— (kiſſing the ladies' hands.) Happy fellows! you are to be envied.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Grev.
sp.p: So are you. We have received happineſs, you have given it.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Your fortunes, ſir, will be our peculiar care.

sp.speaker: Roſ
sp.p: Thank you, dear ladies; but, with your permiſſion, I'll ſtick to my trade.
sp.l: And oh! could all my pray'rs but gain this lot,
To raiſe my pulpit nightly on this ſpot;
Then your poor Auctioneer would prize his ſtation,
While you vouchſafed one nod of approbation.

lg.l: SECRETS worth knowing—Shall I tell you one?
Don't frown, or our poor Bard will be undone.
Change to a grin his preſent woeful phiz,
Laſt year he cur'd your Heart Ache, now cure his.
But leaving him, as we're left here alone,
Suppoſe I tell a ſecret of my own.
Know then, I think—tho' women will be craving.
Your men-folks at the beſt are ſcarce worth having.
No more entire—they go about by halves,
Like legs conſumptive, that have loſt their calves;
What with their crops, ſlouched gait, and ſhort ſurtouts,
Half heads, half tails, half manners, and half boots.
A wife, or an old maid! Aye, that's the queſtion;
Both bitter pills, and bad for our digeſtion;
The prim old maid deteſts all amorous huſſies,
Her nurſery's confin'd to pups and puſſies;
Pug's her gallant, and her dear fondled baby,
Maſter Grimalkin, or grey-ey'd miſs Tabby.
"Man, what an animal! to love to hug,
"Puppies they are; but not like my ſweet pug,
"Prating as parrots, obſtinate as donkies;
"We'd better all lead apes than follow monkies."
The wife poor thing, at firſt ſo blithe and chubby,
Scarce knows again her lover in her hubby;
No more—"my charming dear! my ſweeteſt life,"
'Tis—"ſtir that fire, give me ſome coffee, wife."
"There —now you've burnt my fingers;—what a ninny
"My dog's more nouſe than you, I'll bet a guinea!"
He flies about to ſwallow port by dozens;
She ſtays at home, to mope with aunts and couſins.
Some wives there are, perhaps as well intentioned,
More ſpirited than ſuch as I have mentioned;
Flirt at the opera, gamble at quadrille,
Run down a character, run up a bill;
Should ſpouſe not be at dinner to ſay grace,
Can find a ſubſtitute to fill his place;
Invade man's province, bluſter and look big,
Nor wear the breeches only, but the wig.
Enchanting taſte! each day we change our hue,
White, auburn, grizzle, tye-wig, ſcratch or queue.
The red-hair'd laſs, to hide her golden nob,
Tucks up her treſſes in a nut-brown bob.
And full blown dames, thro' time a little flaxen,
Conceal that outrage by a coal-black caxen,
Nay, proſing belies, however bald the pate,
Can by this means inſure a tête-a-tête.
To ſhew I prize the mode, and would not mock it,
I carry all my graces in my pocket,
Theſe are the native charms with which I ſhine, (takes out a wig.))
A ſtampt receipt will prove that they are mine. (puts on the wig.)
How do I look? Methinks 'tis grand to move (walks about with wig on.)
Beneath the covert of this curly grove.
It ſhields one too; for, ſhould ſome wag, in ſcoff,
Aſſault my ſcratch, he can but ſcratch it off.
Shall I, in future, then, this helmet wear?
Decree, and I'll obey you to a Hair.

div.head: NEW PUBLICATIONS PRINTED FOR T. N. LONGMAN, No. 39, Paternoſter-Row.
div.p: 1. WALSINGHAM; or, the PUPIL of NATURE; a Domeſtic Story, interſperſed with Poetry. By MARY ROBINSON, Author of Angelina, Poems, &c. &c. In Four large Volumes, 12mo. Price 16s. ſewed.
2. FAMILY SECRETS, Literary and Domeſtic. By Mr. PRATT.
div.q: Concerning thoſe things wherein men's lives and perſons are moſt converſant. BACON.
div.p: In five large volumes, 12mo. Price 1l. 5s. Boards.
div.q:
Mr. Pratt has introduced to a numerous ſet of readers a novel that has the merit of being at once tender, pathetic, and full of love; and, which may be a more uncommon circumſtance, of love mixed with the greateſt diſcretion.
Monthly Review, May 1797.

In the volumes before us, there are ſeveral beautiful and affecting ſtrokes of nature.
Analytical Review, April 1797.
div.p: 3. A GOSSIP's STORY and LEGENDARY TALE. By Mrs. WEST, Author of Advantages of Education, &c. In two Volumes 12mo. Price 7s. in Boards.
div.q:
We can recommend this ſtory as uniting to a great degree of intereſt the rarer qualities of good ſenſe, and an accurate knowledge of mankind. The grammatical errors and vulgariſms which diſgrace many even of our moſt celebrated novels, have here no place; and ſeveral of the ſhorter poetical pieces interſperſed through the work, have very conſiderable merit. Amuſement is combined with utility, and fiction is inliſted in the cauſe of virtue and practical philoſophy.
Monthly Review, January 1797.
div.p: 4. CLARA DUPLESSIS and CLAIRANT: The HISTORY of a FAMILY of FRENCH EMIGRANTS. Tranſlated from the German. In Three Volumes, 12mo. Price 10s. 6d. Boards.

q.p: This pathetic novel, or relation of facts, has been deſervedly ſucceſsful in its, native country, and at Paris.—
The characters are drawn with a truth of nature which is truly admirable.

div.p: 5. ANECDOTES of TWO WELL KNOWN FAMILIES. Written by a Deſcendant, and dedicated to the firſt Female Pen in England. Prepared for the Preſs, by Mrs. PARSONS. In Two Vols. 12mo. Price 10s. 6d. in Boards.
6. AN OLD FRIEND WITH A NEW FACE; a Novel. By Mrs. PARSONS. In Three Volumes. Price 10s. 6d. Boards.

7. BIOGRAPHICAL, LITERARY, and POLITICAL ANECDOTES, of-ſeveral of the moſt EMINENT PERSONS of the PRESENT AGE; particularly the Dukes of Grafton, Leeds, Dorſet, and Rutland; Lords Townſhend, Orford, Marchmont, Mansfield, Camden, Temple, Nugent, and Sackville; Biſhops of Hereford and Oſſory; Right Hon. George Grenville, Charles Townſhend; Sir James Caldwell, Sir Grey Cooper, Sir John Dalrymple, Serjeant Adair, Dr. Franklin, and many others. Never before printed; in Three Volumes. Price 18s.
The Monthly Critics, who have already reviewed this new work, ſpeak of it in the following words:

The writers of the Monthly Revicw for laſt month ſay, "We cannot diſmiſs theſe volumes without obſerving, that they contain a conſiderable portion of political information. The work will, by its diſcerning readers, be characterized as highly intereſting; and it will prove particularly ſo to thoſe who ſtill remember the times to which the anecdotes here recorded are referable. To the future hiſtorian alſo it will afford much aſſiſtance, by contributing, in many inſtances, towards the means of information, which, but for publications of this kind, might be utterly conſigned to oblivion.

The writers of the Analytical Review for January laſt, ſay, "The work before us will be found particularly intereſting to thoſe who wiſh to obtain an idea of the management of ſtate affairs in this country, during the whole of the preſent reign."

The writers of the Gentleman's Magazine for January laſt, ſay, "Theſe volumes are written by the author of the Anecdotes of the late Earl of Chatham, and are not inferior to that work either in intereſt or intelligence. Thoſe perſons who are fond of reading the political anecdotes of their own times, particularly from the year 1760 to the year 1780, (an important period), which, the writer aſſures us, have not been printed, will receive fiom this work much pleaſure and information."

The writers of the European Magazine, ſay, "The editor of theſe volumes is entitled to the thanks of the public, for preſerving many facts which otherwiſe might have fallen into oblivion. The reader will find entertainment and information in them, and the future inveſtigator of the acts of the preſent reign will meet with ſome valuable materials to exerciſe his ſagacity upon, which are to be no where elſe found, and which will ſerve to guide him through the obſcure paths of political fineſſe."
8. The ANECDOTES of LORD CHATHAM's LIFE. The Sixth Edition. In Three Volumes, 8vo. Price 18s. Boards.
div.q:
The author has made a valuable Collection of Anecdotes, eſpecially of the late and moſt conſpicuous part of Lord Chatham's Life; and of other matters connected with it. He ſays he is not conſcious of having advanced one falſehood: We give credit to his declaration, having found no cauſe to doubt it.
Monthly Review, May 1792.

q.p: A greater number of curious and intereſting anecdotes, concerning public affairs, have not appeared ſince the days of Sir William Temple, than are to be found in this work.
We cannot diſmiſs this article without acknowledging, that it throws a great and new light upon the occurences and events of more than half a century of our hiſtory.

div.p: 9. A RESIDENCE in FRANCE, during the Years 1792, 3, 4, & 5; deſcribed in a Series of Letters from an ENGLISH LADY, with general and incidental Remarks on the French Character and Manners. Prepared for the Preſs by JOHN GIFFORD Eſq. In Two Volumes, 8vo. Price 14s. Boards. The Third Edition.
div.q:
It is only juſtice to ſay, that the ſtyle is as poliſhed as the matter is intereſting and important: nor have we any doubt that the book will remain a permanent monument of the taſte and talents of the writer.
British Critick, April 1797.
div.p: 10. GLEANINGS THROUGH WALES, HOLLAND, and WESTPHALIA; with Views of Peace and War at Home and Abroad. To which is added, HUMANITY; or, The Rights of Nature: A Poem. Reviſed and corrected. By Mr. PRATT. In Three Volumes, 8vo. Price One Guinea in Boards. Third Edition.
div.q:
We have found ſo many lively and pleaſant exhibitions of manners, ſo many amuſing and intereſting anecdotes, and ſo many obſervations and reflections, gay and grave, ſportive and ſentimental, (all expreſſed in a gay and familiar ſtyle,) better ſuited to the purpoſe than ſentences laboured with artificial exactneſs, that we cannot but recommend it to our readers as a highly amuſing and intereſting performance.
Analytical Review, Jan. 1796.
div.p: 11. An HISTORY, or ANECDOTES of the REVOLUTION in RUSSIA, in the Year 1762. Tranſlated from the French of M. DERULHIERE. With an elegant Head of the late EMPRESS. Second Edition. Price 4s. ſewed.

q.p: The grounds of M. De Rulhiere's information ſeem indiſputable, and his readers appear to have every reaſon to be ſatisfied with his diſcernment, in unfolding the motives and circumſtances that concurred in bringing about this ſtriking event. He is no ſervile copier, but has drawn his characters, and deſcribed his ſcenes, with the hand of a maſter.
We ſhall only add, that we have ſeldom met with more intereſting original anecdotes, than thoſe that are contained in the little work which we have now reviewed.

p.hi: In the Preſs, and ſpeedily will be publiſhed.

div.p: The LIFE of CATHARINE II. EMPRESS of RUSSIA. An enlarged Tranſlation from the French, by a Gentleman many Years reſident at Peterſburgh. In Three Volumes, 8vo. Price One Guinea in Boards. Embelliſhed with Seven elegant Portraits, and a Map of Ruſſia.
